stages.headline: Nervous system settling
stages.summary: At this stage, it is common that your body feels alert, restless, or tense. What you are experiencing now usually means your nervous system is recalibrating.
stages.reassurance: Nothing is wrong — this phase typically passes when sleep and hydration steady.
stages.focus: Keep routines simple. Reduce demands and protect recovery windows.

stages.headline: Withdrawal peak normalization
stages.summary: At this stage, withdrawal signals can peak and feel erratic. What you are experiencing now usually means your system is clearing the last strong chemical cues.
stages.reassurance: Nothing is wrong — this phase typically passes as the first week closes.
stages.focus: Normalize the spikes. Short, repeated resets beat long battles.

stages.headline: Habit decoupling
stages.summary: At this stage, cravings are often more contextual than chemical. What you are experiencing now usually means old cues are losing power.
stages.reassurance: Nothing is wrong — this phase typically passes as new routines become automatic.
stages.focus: Replace the cue, not the willpower. Keep the day predictable.

stages.headline: Identity shift
stages.summary: At this stage, the mind starts to accept a new baseline. What you are experiencing now usually means identity is catching up to behavior.
stages.reassurance: Nothing is wrong — this phase typically passes as the new normal feels quieter.
stages.focus: Act like the new baseline is already true. Keep it understated.

stages.headline: Baseline recalibration
stages.summary: At this stage, the system is rebalancing without constant noise. What you are experiencing now usually means your baseline is stabilizing.
stages.reassurance: Nothing is wrong — this phase typically passes as confidence becomes quiet.
stages.focus: Protect the baseline. No pressure, just consistency.

spikeMode.title: Spike mode
spikeMode.subtitle: Short, concrete steps for the next 20 minutes.
steps: Drink water and change your room or posture.
Do one craving tool, then reassess.
spikeMode.note: No long-term thinking needed right now. Just the next step.

carrSteps.title: Relief vs trap
carrSteps.reframe: Nicotine only eases the discomfort it created.
carrSteps.microProof: What did the urge promise to fix today?
carrSteps.action: Write the promise in one line, then wait 90 seconds.
carrSteps.freedomStatement: Relief is the end of a loop, not a reward.

carrSteps.title: Urges are short
carrSteps.illusion: An urge means I need it
carrSteps.reframe: Urges are short alarms. They fade even if you do nothing.
carrSteps.microProof: How long did your last urge last?
carrSteps.action: Set a 2-minute timer and watch the peak fade.
carrSteps.freedomStatement: You do not have to obey a feeling.

carrSteps.title: You are not deprived
carrSteps.reframe: Most suffering is the fear of losing something.
carrSteps.microProof: What do you think you are missing right now?
carrSteps.action: Name the loss, then name what you gain instead.
carrSteps.freedomStatement: You are not losing a comfort. You are leaving a trap.

carrSteps.title: Trigger rewriting
carrSteps.reframe: Triggers are cues. You can rewrite the response.
carrSteps.microProof: Which cue starts the loop most often?
carrSteps.action: Change the cue once today: move rooms or shift the routine.
carrSteps.freedomStatement: Cues are not commands. They are invitations.

carrSteps.title: Identity shift
carrSteps.illusion: I am a user trying to stop
carrSteps.reframe: You are a non-user learning a new baseline.
carrSteps.microProof: What does a non-user do at your hardest time?
carrSteps.action: Write one line that starts with: I am someone who...
carrSteps.freedomStatement: Freedom is an identity, not a decision.

carrLenses.line: Nicotine promises relief from a discomfort it created.
carrLenses.question: What did the urge promise it would fix?

carrLenses.line: The fear of losing it hurts more than the urge itself.
carrLenses.question: What are you afraid you will miss today?

carrLenses.line: Urges are short loops, not needs.
carrLenses.question: If you waited two minutes, what would change?

carrLenses.line: You are not deprived. You are stepping out of a trap.
carrLenses.question: What are you gaining by not using?

carrLenses.line: Triggers are cues. You can rewrite the response.
carrLenses.question: Which cue is loudest today?

spikeReframes.It will calm me: The calm is just the end of withdrawal. It passes whether you feed it or not.
spikeReframes.I will focus: Focus returns when the loop quiets. A two-minute delay proves it.
spikeReframes.I need it: You feel the loop, not a need. It fades on its own.
